div.p: 1. VI. Good Friday.

Randolph— Burwell. S— applies to be Naval Store keeper in the place of Coll. Brearly; and that he be appointed a General Indian Agent in Arkansas Terry— Appointment 29. March of Jonathan Knight as Commissioner to carry into effect the fourth Section of the Act of 3. March 1825 for the continuation of the Cumberland Road—
M’Comb, Genl.— for the Instructions to Wever and to Knight— M’Adams road.
2. V:45John Gardiner— Ex-clerk in the general Land-Office—to be re-instated.

list.item: H. Clay— about Cheves and Jackson, Commissioners— Their differences.—
Letter from Charlton of Savannah— Why not appointed Minister to Mexico.
Mr Clay wishes to introduce two new Clerks into the Dept. of State— Kendall.
Jeremy Robinson— Poinsett’s story of him— A native of Massachusetts.
Captain Reid of Privateer Genl. Armstrong, for J. G. Swift’s place— Or Maury’s.

div.p: 3. VI:30. Snow— Easter—

list.item: Heard Little. Galatians 6.8— Communion, and exhortation
Read Johnson’s Sermon—on Marriage.
Baker— Psalm 116.1–9. Little— James 3.13.

div.p: 4. VI:15. Removal of books.— W. Brown with check for 2. and 3. March.

list.item: March of New-York—from Charleston— 1. pipe of Madeira Wine every year
H. Clay— Draft of Letter to H. U. Addington, upon Slave-trade Convention.
Correspondence with J. H. Eaton, about Kremer’s affair
Coll. Jones, with Major Lomax from fortress Monroe— School there
C. Hay with a Warrant on Treasy. Contingent charge prior to 1824. Appropriation symbols
Captain W. Worthington with Proceedings of a Militia Court martial D.C.
Mrs Turner from Georgetown, to hire the house—and take boarders.
Hopkinson, Joseph here, after dinner

div.p: 5. VI:15.Levi S. Burr— for appointment of Smith as Justice of Peace in 6th. Ward.

list.item: Wheaton— Joseph— for Appointment of Charles Lowes, Coml. Agent Kingston Jamaica—
Phillips— Captain to be reinstated; appointed Commr. of the Navy, and soon resign.
Clay— H.— Complaint of J. C. Jones against Spanish Consul Boston.
Application of French Minister, about the Commercial Convention.
Correspondence with J. H. Eaton— returned— Answer to Salmon about Mullowny—
Seaton W. W.— to recommend R. Little for place, and Causici for employment—
Hopkinson— Joseph dined with us— John missing and anxiety—
Sullivan, G. came in after dinner.
Mrs. Adams, Mary and Elizabeth went to sleep at the President’s House—

div.p: 6. VI.Gideon. Jacob— With Letter from P. Doddrige, in favour of Jonn. Jackson—

list.item: Pettis— For an appointment as Commr. at Mobile—on Farrow & Harris’s Applicn.
Wirt—W. with Judge Carr, from Virginia.
Hopkinson— Jos. and his Son. A. H.— Collector’s Office at Philadelphia.
Pleasonton— S— with recommendn. of Jos. Preston as Light-house keeper— Salem Masstts
Urges earnestly an appointment for E Wyer.
Walk with G. Sullivan— He. Joseph Hopkinson, and A. Hamilton Hopkinson dined with us

div.p: 7. VII.Dr Thornton— to take leave— Complaint—

list.item: Dr Watkins— for his Son to be Consul at Manchester or Birmingham. Lighthouse
Letters from R. King and S. L. Southard
H. Clay— Conversation with Mareuil about Commercial Convention
Instructions to R. King— Cheves and Jackson— Waiving of Interest
Despatch from Baron Tuyll, about discriminating duties.
Correspondence with J. H. Eaton, published by Eaton.
Removed to the Presidential house— symbols
Hopkinson—Joseph.
Macomb— Genl. about the continuation of the Cumberland road
Dined at the house with Mrs Adams, Mary C. Hellen &. Eliz. C. Adams
John dined at G. Sullivan’s—with Hopkinson’s Senr. and junr.
Hopkinson and his Son— Evening here.

div.p: 8. V. Sunrise, beautiful— symbols 44 symbols 45 symbols

list.item: Walk to my house before breakfast. Met G. Sullivan
After breakfast returned to remove—
D. Brent there— Instructions to A. H. Everett. H. Clay.
At one Received Antonio Jose Cañaz Envoy from Guatemala, with H. Clay and Fernando Valero, Secretary of Legation— Going to New-York.
Wirt W— to recommend Captn. Reid

div.p: 9. V.45.Southard Saml L. returned from New-Jersey with his family.

list.item: Russell— Gilbert C.— Wishes Major de Russy to be arrested. After conversation says he is satisfied without it.
Ironside— George with a new Great Seal, engraved by Masi.
Tingey— Commodore— Enquiry concerning M. L. Hill and Wingate. Examination of Midshipmen— A. H. Hopkinson approved.
Reid. Captain, of Privateer Genl. Armstrong. Going to New York to-morrow.
King— Charles— His father wishes John King to go with him as Secy of Legation.
Brown— Genl— Of J. H. Eaton’s publication— Genl. Jackson’s Letter to Swartwout.

Clay— H.— Obregon’s complaint of W. Taylor. Blockade of the Castle of St. John d’Ulna. Principles of blockade— Rights to be maintained with due regard to Mexico. Answer from Addington, upon the Slave-trade Convention Note—
The proposition from R. King; reasonable, and should be complied with—
Walk— Met Dr. Watkins—walk with him to Capitol Hill— Home alone.
Charles King dined with us—and at Tea—

div.p: 10. V:45. At St. John’s Heard Hawley— Luke 12.20.21.

list.item: Charles King— here in the morning, and dined with us— Goes to-morrow for NY
Presbyterian Church. A Stranger Romans 3.31. Met S. L. Southard.
Lee— W.— Evening here.

div.p: 11. VI:Graham— George— Choctaw Treaty, School-fund— Art. 7. U.S. Laws. Vol. 6. p. 777

list.item: Recommends investment in Mississippi State-Bank— No Account of this fund settled at the Treasury— 7000 dollars now in Bank— Will be 30000
Surveyor General. M’Ree has not yet gone to St. Louis. Govr. Clarke must be again commissioned as Temporary Surveyor
Land-grants— 42. Land Offices— Various forms of Patents—
Graham going on a flying visit to Kentucky.
Forbes, James G— for place— Naval depot in Florida— Pensacola— Tampa Bay.
Southard, Saml. L. with Captain Phillips’s Papers—takes them away, to add C. Goldsborough’s answers to interrogatories.
Macomb— Genl. introducing De Witt Clinton junr.
Clay, H— Answer to Rebello— Letters from D. Webster and E. Ingersoll.
W. C. Somerville’s wish to go to Naples— J. J. Appleton
Visit to Alexandria on Wednesday— 4 or 5 O’Clock.
Southard, S. L.— Took the papers in case of Mebane— Attorney General’s opinion.
Hamilton Collr. Pensacola— District Attorney to be ordered to prosecute trespassers. Morel Marshal of Georgia’s claim for keeping Negroes— Southard’s opinion unchanged.
Phillips Captain here—to be reinstated in the Navy.

div.p: 12. V:15—George 24— symbols— A. Hodgson—

list.item: Alexander. Amos— for place— Land-surveying &c. With recommendatory Letters.
Fletcher— of Alexandria, for a Clerkship—&c— With a recommy. certificate.
Nourse. Major— Late acting adjutant General, for place or employment—
Swann and Cazenove—Messrs— Comee—from Alexandria— dinner tomorrow—
Southard, S. L. Choctaw School Reservation— A trust to P.U.S. whether to place it in Mississippi State Bank Stock.
Case of Captain Phillips— Papers to be sent me with Goldsborough’s answers.
Angus— Mr Monroe’s Letter in his favour— His threats of personal violence.
M’Lean— John P.M.G— Hour of departure for Alexandria to-morrow.
Walk— Call on T. B. Johnson—found him at dinner.

div.p: 13. V:45.Ringgold. Tench— Marshal— Going to Alexandria to dine.

list.item: Brent. D— Gave him papers, belonging to the Department of State.
Laws relating to the District of Columbia— No collection of them.
Militia Laws— To enquire at the War Department.
Clay, H— very unwell. Letter from Nathl. Silsbee about Jery. Robinson.
Proposed omission from Letter to Rebello— Agreed.

Had a Conference yesterday of 2. hours with Mareuil, about commercial relations with France— Threats of terminating the Convention and resorting to prohibitions— Mareuil will so advise his Government— Clay thinks they will not terminate the convention—
Signed eight Commissions of Consuls, nominated and appointed by Mr Monroe altered the form of Commission to conform to the fact.
Signed Commission, temporary to W. Clark, acting Surveyor Genl. from 4. March
Southard S. L.— brought me the papers in the cases of Captain Philiips and Angus.
Sullivan, George— a visit— Conversation about Cicero and S. Dexter.
M’Lean J. P.M.G. came and accompanied me to Alexandria.
Slacum and Moore came from Alexandria. to go with me
Steam boat surprise— Captain Taylor— Went from Wharf below the bridge.

div.p:
Southard— Wirt— M’Lean, and Ringgold went with us— Clay, too unwell to go, sent an excuse— Marine Corps band of Music— Left the wharf at 3:30 P.M. Half-past four reached Alexandria— Received by Judge Cranch and Cazenove— Dinner at Alexandria—about 70— The Mayor Roberts presided.
At 8. P.M— returned to the Steam-boat, Judge Cranch and Cazenove with me to the Boat— Southard, Wirt, M’Lean and Ringgold in company, and Mr Moore of Alexandria— Reached wharf at Washington about 9.— Ringgold came home with me— Found T. B. Johnson here. Mr Monroe sent an apology
14. V:30—Rice— Luther, introducing the Revd. Mr Niles from Ohio, going to Vermont.

Phillips— Captn. Isaac— for a decision upon his Memorial. I told him I had not Power to re-instate him— He said I had advised him to address his memorial to the President— I replied that I was not acquainted with the facts—and did not know he had been dismissed from the Service— He referred to my father’s Letters to Dr Waterhouse— I declined a discussion of them—but informed him that a decision upon his Memorial should be communicated to him from the Navy Department.

Brown Genl— with inspection Report from General Gaines recommending removal of Garrisons from Michillimackinac and Detroit— Brown agrees with Gaines but on the remonstrance of Govr Cass and the Legislative Council of Michigan, orders have been given for the Garrisons to be continued— Brown has no fear of Indian hostilities there— But recommends attention to the Post at St. Mary’s— Thinks the troops at Detroit may be employed on the road.
Bainbridge— Como— Arrived the 12th. with his family. Objects as Commissioner of the Navy to sit on the Court of enquiry upon Commodore Porter.
Brent, Daniel— Letter from Editors of Baltimore American, about transmission of their paper— Burch’s Digest of Washington Corporation By-Laws.

Munroe— T. P.M. Letter from his Son in Poland— Wishes an Equipment of Infantry Soldier, to present to the G. Duke Constantine— Calhoun Secy of War wrote to C. Irvine Commissary of Supplies to furnish one— Irvine asked for an Order from the Secy of War— Calhoun then told Munroe he must pay for the equipment. The late P.U.S. wished to comply; but went out of Office re infecta— I told Munroe, that the order should be given from the War Department, and the payment made from the contingent fund of foreign intercourse.
Sale at auction of our household furniture this day—
Examined all the papers of the case of Captain Phillips.
15. V.Porter, a young man, with an Officer— Wishes assistance to pay his bill.
Graham— George— to authorise the sale of public Land at Sagana, Michigan Territory.
Letter from John Biddle, Register at Detroit— I underwrote, the Sale approved.
Letter from W. Taylor— Receiver at Cahaba, resigning— Large defaulter—
Letter from A. Anderson late examiner— Lacock since appointed— List of Land-Offices, Registers and Receivers left with me by Mr Graham
Barbour James. Secy War— Application from Duval, Agent to the Cherokee Indians West of the Mississippi, to change the bounds of their Lands as marked by Treaty.
Genl Macomb, G. Sullivan and DeWitt Clinton junr— dined with us. symbols
It can be done only by another Treaty— People of Arkansas wish for the entire removal of the Cherokees— Inexpediency of a partial change—
Appointment of a US. District Judge— Western District of Virginia— Pindall, and Caldwell recommended— To appoint about 1. May.

Clay— H— Draft of Instructions to J. M. Forbes approved. King of Naples’s Letter announcing his father’s death, to be answered— Letter from C. Hughes, proposal to sell Island of St. Bartholomew for 500,000 dollars— Despatches from R. Rush— Slave-indemnity Commission— Jackson has delivered the documents furnished by the British Government— Salmon’s application for a second loan of 5 or 6000 dollars— I inclined to accede to it— Mr Clay was reluctant; and I authorised him to decline the advance— Appleton’s destination changed— A Letter has been written to him announcing it, and the allowance, at the rate of 4500 a year for his new destination— Public dinners and Mr Monroe’s tours.
Vollen— A man who comes for assistance having lost two horses.
Christian—to go to Richmond— Wounded at Chippewa—has no pension.
Examined S. Angus’s memorial asking to be restored to his rank in the Navy, or pecuniary relief— And all the Documents— No power to restore.

16. V.Southard S. L. Court of Enquiry upon Commodore David Porter. Letter from Porter to Southard, complaining of delay— Bainbridge’s objections to sitting on the Court considered—not valid— Importance of appointing an Officer Senior to Porter, to preside— Morris and Wadsworth to be the two others.

Case of Captain Isaac Phillips— Conversation relating to it— The Evidence adduced by Phillips, demolishes his own Statements and pretensions— The Letters of Timmons and Fuller; positively contradict him— Goldsborough’s account partially favourable to him— Mr Southard took back the papers to make a supplementary, confidential Report; not to be made public unless it should become necessary.

Samuel Angus’s Memorial—decision in his case as in that of Phillips—no authority in the President to re-instate him— But a Pension equal to half-pay may be allowed him—upon application supported by proof. I give written decisions, in both cases; to be filed in the Department, and copies of all the papers are to be furnished me.

Bulfinch, Charles— introduced a Mr Tanner of Pennsylvania, who has a patent for a Railway invention— Bulfinch wishes to be appointed a visitor at the West-Point examination; to make an excursion after seven years of service without intermission.

Sullivan George— Wishes me to interpose with P. Hagner, 3d. Auditor, to press the examination of the Massachusetts claim documents— Expediency doubtful. State of political parties in Boston— Webster’s standing and popularity. Recent Elections thinly attended—
Lee Richard Bland; for appointment of Coote as Justice of Peace— Mr Lee left with me an application for any moderately lucrative appointment, with a statement of his pretensions.
Havens. Philetus, brought a Letter of Introduction from P. Sharpe.

17. V:30— Heard Little 2. Corinthians 1.12. “For our rejoicing is this, the testimony of our conscience, that in simplicity, and godly sincerity, not with fleshly wisdom, but by the grace of God, we have had our conversation in the world, and more abundantly to you-ward.”
Baker in the Afternoon. — Job. 28.28. “And unto man he said, Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom”— Contrast between Slavish fear, and filial fear.

Little, in the Evening— Mark 12.28. “And one of the scribes came, and having heard them reasoning together, and perceiving that he had answered them well, asked him, which is the first commandment of all? and the six following verses”— He said, don’t be alarmed, at the length of the text— For you will have a very short Sermon
Letter from Commodore David Porter— Impatient and angry.
Letter from Chevalier Brito, with Milhie’s translation of Camoen’s Lusiad’s.
Evening came home in darkness, that could be felt and rain— House locked up, and the Porter Robertson, had carried away the key— Sent for it, and had it returned.
John went to Rockville, and Johnson Hellen came back with him.
18. V:30.Conner, Benjamin, with much to say about the dock-yards and Navy-yards.
Subscription for Say’s American Entomology, Vol. 1. and a Glossary.
M’Cormick Revd. A. Clerk in the Department of State— Morning visit.
Hay— George— Last Evening from Oakhill. Invitation to Mrs Adams to go there with me.
Bullus— Oscar— Midshipman in the Navy— For an appointment as purser.
Lee, William — To ask leave of absence for 8 or 10 days.

Barbour James.— S.W.— Letter from Govr. Troup of Georgia— Settlement of boundary between Georgia and Alabama— A Similar Letter answered 13. July 1824. by J. C. Calhoun. U.S. have no authority to run the line without the Consent of Alabama.

Gave Mr Barbour Letter from Brigadier Genl. Smith of Georgetown, concerning the distribution of Arms to the Militia of the District. Construction of the Act, as to the return of the Arms— Mr Barbour thinks it applicable to all the arms distributed.
Sentence of Court-Martial in the Case of M’Euel approved— Gave the papers to Mr Barbour. Allen Taylor recommended as Judge of Western District of Virginia.
Near— Doctor— Applies for Appointment as Naval Store-keeper at Pensacola.
M’Farland— Revd. John— Subscriptions for Centre College, Danville, Kentucky.
Russell, G. C. with Mr Bowie of Louisiana and Dr Baty of Philadelphia— Visitors. Conversation, about a new Medical School in Philadelphia— Dr. Mitchell &c

Clay. H— Has agreed with Baron Tuyll, upon an indemnity to be made to Bryant and Sturges, by the Russian Government— Instructions to Raguet, returned him the draft—proposing omission of a paragraph, respecting the Slave-trade— St. Domingo— Mr Clay thinks the Independence of the Haytian Government, must shortly be recognized— My objections— Review of the course of the late Administration upon that subject— Discussion— Judge in the Western District of Virginia— Pindall, Caldwell, Taylor, Breckenridge, Doddridge &c— Clerks in the Department— Their punctuality to be stimulated.
Ordered release from prison of Joseph M. Johnson— On Petition.
19. V:15—Carroll— came to apply for a Midshipman’s warrant

row.cell: Commission of Daniel W Smith— Consul at Refugio, Mexico
of Joshua Bond. Consul at Montevideo.

div.p: Beggars, two— of suspicious appearance.
Thomas— the Architect— with copy of his Patent invention for Ship-building.

Barbour James. S.W. with application from Mr Jefferson for a payment of 50000 dollars on account of interest payable to Virginia, by Act of Congress of 3. March 1825 Ch. 108. although the amount is not yet ascertained— The act of 31. January 1823 prohibits advances— This Barbour said was no advance— I thought it questionable, on the Letter of the two Laws; but consented that the payment should be made, in consideration of the object, and the emergency, and the certainty that the sum payable will be larger.
Jones. Coll. R. with his brother-in-Law, Revd. Mr Page, from Virginia, visitors.

Southard— S. L. and Wirt, W. Southard again objects to the appointment of Bainbridge and Morris, Navy Commissioners, on the Court of Inquiry, upon Porter’s conduct. Thinks it unpopular with the Navy, on account of the connection of the Board with the Department, and for other reasons— I agreed that he should appoint Chauncey, Crane and Woodsworth—

Wirt had received recommendations, for the appointment of a Judge for the Western District of Virginia— H. S. G. Tucker recommends Philip Pendleton, and T. SwannR. Page— Wirt is strenuous against Pindall symbols
Scott’s and Clarke’s Commentaries on the Bible and Tacitus Hist: 2.93.
Hilliard—of Boston, from Virginia— Has made a contract to supply Mr Jefferson’s University with books— I spoke of Walton’s Polyglott Bible—for $150. with Castelli’s Lexicon.
Commn.Andrew Miller Bailey— Receiver at Cincinnati— Temporary— signed
Woodside— applied for a subscription to a machine for taking the Latitude
M’Intyre, A— for a Clerkship in 2d. Auditor’s Office, in the place of R. Maury who he says is to be transferred to the Treasury Department.
This day 50 years, since the battle of Lexington.
symbols 20. V:15—Bill, A. H. with a petition from Rutherford for release from prison. Told him he must have a recommendation from one of the judges.
Thomas— Naval Architect. took his papers— Wants to build a Sloop of War at Charlestown.
Brent Daniel— Letter from J. S. Skinner Editor of American Farmer.
Returned to Mr Brent the despatches to State Dept. yesterday received.
Commn. to James M. Greene, as Surgeon’s mate in the Navy, signed.

Ironside— G. A. with draft of Instructions to W. Miller, Charge d’Affaires to Guatemala. Returned him the answer of Mr Clay to Mr Cañaz’s proposals for opening a canal between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
Roberdeau. Coll— concerning the plan for leveling the grounds between the President’s House and the Tyber— New System of weights and measures in England— Plan of the Harbour of Pensacola.

Southard, S. L. with a Letter to D. Porter, announcing the appointment of the Court of Enquiry— B. Conner’s request, for the report upon the Dockyards— Jonathan Jackson’s application for release from imprisonment—and James Sanderson’s, and Richard Veitch’s.— M’Intyre’s application for the Clerkship in the second Auditor’s Office—
Evening occupied upon the Index to my Diary— Began upon the arrears.
21. V.Wirt W. called with Mr Clark from Virginia— A morning visit.

Johnson George— Affairs of the Mills— He promised to bring accounts for Settlement, I offered to reconvey to him, or to any one for him, the whole property for the same Sum I gave for it, with the loss of two years interest— He said he thought he should be able to effect this arrangement— But he must send for his clerk Adams to understand the State of the Accounts, and make his statement to me— He has sent his whole Stock of flour to Providence, Boston, and Portland, for sale upon credit, in the teeth of his stipulations with me.
Brent— Daniel— with despatches from J. M. Forbes and M. Hogan.
Barbour James. S.W— with a Letter from Govr Cass of Michigan Territory of the 4th.

To T. L. M’Kenney, and several enclosures, concerning Chippeway Indians, who last Summer murdered several Citizens of U.S.— The delivery of the Murderers was demanded and not obtained— Cass thinks it necessary to visit them this Spring with a Military force, from Sault St. Marie and perhaps hostility; to which Mr Barbour is much averse— Also proceedings of a Court Martial at West-Point upon Cadet Daniel M’Neal. Sentenced to be dismissed upon the joint opinion of Mr Barbour and Mr Clay. I authorised Barbour to write to B. Baldwin offering him the appointment of judge for the Western district of Virginia.— I inclined to appoint P. Pendleton.

Clay— H— Has settled with Baron Tuyll, the claim of Bryant and Sturges upon the Russian Government for the case of the Pearl on the N.W. Coast— Spoke of the Instructions to Mr Miller as Chargé d’Affaires to Guatemala; and of the answer to Mr Cañaz, on the proposal for opening the passage between the Atlantic and Pacific. Of the
of the Slave indemnity convention, and the great probability that it will prove abortive; or must be carried into effect by a new Negotiation with G.B. Of the appointment of a Judge for the Western District of Virginia and very favourably of Pendleton— But the offer is to be made to Baldwin.

Baker— J. M— here with his son, who went out with H. Nelson, but soon after went to France on pursuits of Medical Study and now returns a graduate. Thinks the present French Medical School the best in the world— Tracing almost all diseases to the inflammation of the alimentary Canal.

M’Lean. John P.M.G— I shewed him S. A. Foote’s Letter, about the expected appointment of a New Postmaster at Stamford, Connecticut— M’Lean said that no such new appointment would be made— There had been complaints against the incumbent Stevens; but they had not been supported.
Evening— Signed 109 Land-grants St. Stephens Alabama— Diary Index.
22. IV:45. At dawn of day— Read of the Law— from Sinai— Hebrew Alphabet.

Brent, Daniel— Brought me a draught of a Letter he had made at Mr Clay’s request to W. Willink of Amsterdam in answer to Letters from the House of Willem and Jan Willink at Amsterdam; announcing the dissolution of that house on the first of March; and that Willem Willink junr. is henceforth to constitute the house alone. And one from Willem Willink jr. soliciting to be continued as the Banker of the United States— I desired Mr Brent to send me the Letters; and thought it would be well, to make some enquiries as to the solidity of the new house— He sent me the Letters.
Calvert— Mr of near Bladensburg for a visit. Lately returned from an excursion to Philadelphia— His eldest Son is at Göttingen.
John dined with Mr Clay— I wrote in the Evening to Professor Everett.
Wirt. W. A.G. came to take leave, going for a few days to Baltimore

Brown— Genl. Had sent me a Letter of June 1823. from Govr. Cass to Calhoun. S.W. and his Brown’s answer to it— Cass’s Letter urged, having troops in force in the Michigan territory, and fortifying Detroit— Brown’s answer shews different views— Brown said he had been much hurt at the order given by me a few days since without consulting him, for continuing the troops at Mackinaw— Under the late Administration these arrangements having been invariably referred to him—and no other answer having been given from the War Department to Cass’s Letter which he had sent me, than his— I told him, that the Memorial of Cass and the remonstrance from the Legislative council of Michigan, had in the absence of Governor Barbour, been sent to me, by the Chief Clerk of the War Department, Major Van de Venter, with a recommendation to issue the order as I did—and I directed the order to issue accordingly supposing that
that Van de Venter had communicated with Genl. Brown before he recommended the issuing of the Order— Genl. Brown declared himself satisfied on this point— But he said Cass’s alarm about an Indian War was very foolish; and he thought the concentration of the troops and the abandonment of all useless Posts very desirable— The General had not finished, when Commodore Tingey came in; but then withdrew. Tingey’s object again was to enquire whether the investigation of the conduct of Mark L. Hill had commenced, and whether I could give an appointment to his Son in Law Wingate— The difficulty is with the Senate, which rejected last year the nomination of him as Collector at Bath— I could give the Commodore no immediate encouragement— Mr George Hay called to take leave, intending to return to-morrow, to Mr Monroe’s at Loudoun. Mr Southard came and introduced Mr Hugh Mercer, from Fredericksburg, Virginia— Messrs. Clay, Barbour, W. C. Somerville, and W. Lee with Captain Isaiah Deane, successively called, followed by Mr Southard, who now came upon business, and occupied my time from breakfast till half past four P.M. without intermission— I then took an hour’s walk; and after dinner another of about half an hour with Mrs Adams— The rest of the Evening in my chamber, writing, with great repugnance, and to little purpose, from the lassitude of weather already approaching the temperature of Summer— Mr and Mrs. G. Sullivan were below— Mr Wirt left with me a Letter to him recommending Allen Taylor, as judge of the Western District of Virginia; and a recommendation of J. P. Kennedy of Baltimore, for a Secretary of Legation abroad, signed by several members of the late Congress from Maryland.

Mr Clay had sent me several despatches from R. C. Anderson at Bogota, from R. Rush at London, and from C. Hughes at Stockholm— The Mexican Minister Obregon had proposed to him that the United States should send Ministers to the proposed American Congress at Panama. Mr Clay strongly inclines to it, and proposed a cabinet consultation concerning it— In the National Journal of this morning, there is a paper relating to this project, which is of great importance—and besides the objects there noticed as fit subjects for the deliberations of this Congress, that of endeavouring to establish American principles of maritime, belligerent and neutral Law, is an additional interest of infinite magnitude. Clay thought it would be a good mission for Mr Gallatin— This is a grain of mustard-seed— Mr Clay read me part of a Letter from P. B. Porter in New-York, asserting that De Witt Clinton is inveterately hostile to the present Administration of the General Government, which I hear also from various other sources— Clay left also with me a Letter from C. Hammond at Cincinnati Ohio, containing some information. Mr Barbour brought me a Letter from Mr Quincy, Mayor of Boston, relating to the Execution of a Law of Congress of the last Session, containing an appropriation for the preservation of the Islands in Boston Harbour— And a Letter from Newell a Clerk in the War Department, enquiring if the Clerks in the public Offices are not exempted from the performance of militia duty by the Act of Congress of 8. May 1792. under the denomination of Executive Officers— I thought they were— I returned to Mr Barbour the papers from Govr. Cass, relating to the Indian murderers, and the proceedings of the Court
Court-martial at West-Point, on the Cadet M’Neal— Mr Southard, brought a Letter from General Swift, Surveyor of the Port of New-York proposing to make experiments to ascertain the comparative merit of Hydrometers, for the execution of a Law of the last Session authorising the Secretary of the Treasury to change the hydrometer hitherto prescribed by Law in the Custom houses (Dycas’s).— I thought the Law did not authorise experiments— But requested Mr Southard to ascertain upon what representations, the Law authorising the change was enacted.
24. IV:45. symbols 26.27. Tabernacle and altar. symbols

Heard Bedell of Philadelphia, from Ezekiel 37.3— [“]And he said unto me, Son of Man, can these bones live? and I answered, O Lord God, thou knowest.”— An emphatic, and eloquent, but illiberal and bigoted discourse— In two divisions—first a type of the condition of the Jewish Nation at the time of the prophesy— Secondly a type of the condition of the world at this time—with an episode of invective upon the unitarian heresy. Mr and Mrs Frye— W. S. Smith, and Eugene and Aaron Vail came as visitors.

Afternoon at Dr Balch’s Church at Georgetown— Reunion of the Sunday Schools, 15 in number; near 800 children of each Sex— Second annual Report read— Prayer by Dr Laurie. Sermon by Dr Staughton, from Galatians 6.9. “And let us not be weary in well-doing; for in due Season we shall reap if we faint not.”— Address by Mr Bedell— Told the Story of Moses saved by Thermutis, and uttered a philippic against the unholy league— Psalm read by Mr Baker—dismissing benediction by Dr. Balch— Church crowded—past six when I came home. Mrs Sullivan dined with us— Mr Sullivan and Elizabeth C. Adams went this morning to Baltimore. I read Colman’s Sermons 5 and 6. on the miraculous character of Jesus and that Christianity is a divine communication— His doctrine seems to be Arianism—
25. IV:45. symbols 28.29. A. M. D. Jackson before Breakfast.

Mrs Elizabeth Baker, Revd. Isaac Hunter of Michigan. D. Brent twice a Mr Rankin, of Tennessee, T. Cook, A. B. Woodward, H. Clay. Genl. Brown with Genl. Gaines and Lieut. Butler. Captain Isaiah Deane, Genl. Brown again, with Genl. Wilkin heretofore M.H.R. from New-York. James Barbour, and R. B. Maury— These visitors absorbed the day from eight in the morning till half past four P.M— I walked a quarter of an hour, and we dined— After dinner, I rode with my Son John to Greenleaf’s Point— Mr Clay, Mrs. Johnstons of Louisiana, Mr and Mrs Frye, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, and Linnaeus Smith spent the Evening with us— Johnson Hellen returned to Rockville—

Jackson came to solicit a Clerkship— Mrs Baker to intreat me to release her husband, committed to a loathsome jail, yesterday, by an order of Judge Thruston, for the indecency of beating a child of his own on a Sunday— Mr Hunter to ask for contribution for building a Methodist Church at Detroit in the Michigan Territory. Mr T. Cook, merely for a visit— Judge Woodward, to shew me Letters he had received from Mr Jefferson, and Mr Madison relating to the Author of the Constitution of Virginia— He also shewed me a Letter from my father—and I read to him in Niles’s Register of
of last June, my father’s Letter to Nathan Webb of 12. October 1755. Mr Woodward spoke of his project for the Establishment of a Department of the Interior; which I told him I thought Congress would not for some time Sanction— I mentioned to him the reason assigned to me by Mr Monroe, for omitting the recommendation of it, in his last annual message. Which was that having recommended in the same Message an increase of the Judges of the Supreme Court, he was apprehensive it would have too much the appearance of a projecting Spirit to recommend also additions to the Executive Department— Mr Clay informed me that Mr Addington had requested that I would appoint a time to receive him, to make a communication from his Government of congratulation upon my Election— I fixed to-morrow at one O’Clock, but observed that if it was a written communication, a copy of it should be previously furnished to the Department of State— Mr Brent afterwards made enquiry of Mr Addington, and found it was only an Instruction from the foreign Department— Mr Clay observed that his health was so much affected, and he was so confident of deriving benefit from a Journey, as he always had under the same complaint, that he proposed, preparing Instructions for Mr R. King, upon the single point of the Slave-Indemnity Commision, and to postpone the remaining topics, until after his return from Kentucky; so that Mr King may embark without delay— To this I readily assented, convinced that it would occasion no real delay. It was also agreed that Mr Somerville should be allowed to postpone his departure for Sweden, till July or August to accomplish his matrimonial project with Miss Cora Livingston at New-Orleans. His Salary not to commence till he shall depart upon his Mission— Despatch from James Brown at Paris with confidential copies of the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs Zea-Bermudez’s answer to the notification from the British Cabinet of their intention to recognize the South-American Independents; and of a Letter from London, shewing the dissatisfaction of Russia, Austria and Prussia, at the British recognition— Genl. Brown’s two visits with Gaines and Butler, and with Wilkins were merely of civility— Mr Barbour, brought the papers of two Officers in the army, brevet Major Lomax, and Captain R. L. Baker, who claim to be restored to rank which they lost by transfer at their own proposal; and of a question concerning the purchase of ordnance; whether from the same founderies as for several years back; or by advertisement and competition.

26. V.Southard. S. L. Proposes to pay three Millions of the Six per Cent Stocks redeemable this year, on the first of July, and the other three Millions on the first of October— There will not be funds in the Treasury to pay the whole on the first of July— I asked him if the Bank U.S. would not undertake to pay the whole on 1. July. Receiving interest upon any balance which might be due from the Treasury untill refunded— It could not exceed ninety days—probably not sixty. He will enquire but thinks this would not be legal. Revd. D. Baker— Transfer of Pew N. 63. from Mrs Meigs, towards payment of my Note. Dorcas Society. He left with me Miller’s Letters against the Unitarians— Allison came to solicit a Clerkship; with a Letter of recommendation from Mr Monroe. Jos. Anderson the Comptroller, came and introduced Genl. Champion of Connecticut and the Revd. MrSkinner
Skinner of Philadelphia— At one Mr H. U. Addington, Chargé d’Affaires from Great-Britain came in form, and said he was instructed by his Government to offer me their Congratulations upon my Election to the Office of President of the United States, and that he could not execute those Instructions better than by reading them to me— He accordingly took the despatch from his Pocket, and read it to me— It was complimentary, and dwelt especially on the idea, that having myself been at one time the representative of my Country at the Court of Great-Britain, I had been enabled fully to appretiate the friendly dispositions of the British Government; and it mentioned in terms of high commendation, Mr Vaughan, the newly appointed Minister coming to this Country— Mr Addington said he had also a private Letter from Mr G. Canning, concerning the election which he gave me to read— It was merely an assurance, that his personal wishes had been altogether favourable to my Election in preference to all the other Candidates—particularly as he had supposed, that if the Election had fallen upon another, I should not have continued in the Department of State. I desired Mr Addington, to assure his Government that I had received with sensibility this Communication— That I considered it among the most fortunate circumstances of my Life, that I had been instrumental, first in restoring Peace between our two Countries; then in adjusting important concerns of Navigation and Commerce between them by Conventions, which had promoted harmony and friendly intercourse, afterwards by my residence for two years as the Minister of the United States in England, and finally for eight years as a member of the late Administration— That it had been one of my Predecessors most ardent wishes to cultivate a good understanding with Great-Britain— That concurring with that desire, it would still influence my conduct. The policy of the Government would remain the same— Mr Vaughan when he should arrive would be very cordially received. The character given of him by Mr Canning would ensure him a welcome, and I hoped he would have every reason to be satisfied with his residence here. And I took this occasion to say that whatever his own destination was to be, no person could by his conduct make himself more acceptable than he had done— If he was to remain here, we should be gratified; if he should leave us we should regret the loss of him, and hope that he would go only in the line of promotion— He was much pleased with this testimonial, and said he had never been any where more kindly treated than here. I desired him to thank Mr Canning for the friendly expressions of his private Letter; and to say that I had before been indebted to him for obliging attentions, which were well remembered, although the acknowledgment of them had been neglected by me— I alluded to his having sent to me through Mr Rush a copy of one of his Speeches— I added that as a manifestation of my earnest wish for harmony with Great Britain, I had selected for the Mission to that Court, as he was no doubt aware a person, who had already been many years in England in that capacity, and who had been always advantageously known, and much esteemed
esteemed there— Finally I desired him to express the great satisfaction which I had felt, and with the concurring sentiment of this Nation, at the determined stand taken, recently by his Government in recognizing the Southern Nations of this Hemisphere. It was delightful to find Great-Britain openly and explicitly pledged in support of liberal principles of National Independence, and the more so, as we were well informed the taking of that step had produced a crisis, requiring at once all the firmness and Prudence, which any Statesman could display— He said he would not fail in the proper manner to communicate to his Government these remarks— Coll. Henderson and another Officer called while I was engaged and I could not see them. Francis C. Hall, came to solicit an appointment as an Officer in the Marine Corps— He brought with him numerous recommendations to which he very fervently added his own— L. Cheves came to take leave but I did not see him. D. Brent to inform me of the purport of Mr Addington’s communication, but it had been already made— Dr Kent paid me a visit, and recommended again W. G. D. Worthington for some Office— W. C. Somerville came, and repeated the application for leave to postpone his departure upon his Mission to Sweden for about three Months to go and be married at New-Orleans—to which I assented, but observed that it would be for his own interest to repair as soon as possible to his post; believing that considerable changes were even now taking place in the politics of Europe, and that there would be much information to be collected and transmitted— After a solitary walk, I called at C. B. King’s, to enquire of the Portrait of Mr Monroe, which I had asked him to paint for me, but he said that he had been unable to obtain a sitting from him before he went away— Mr Monroe had invited him to go and paint him at Oakhill. Elizabeth C. Adams returned from Baltimore with G. Sullivan. Mrs Adams very unwell— Confined almost the whole day to her bed.

27. V.Mrs. Adams was extremely ill the whole Night. Up, two or three times. Rainy Morning— Barbour S.W. came concerning the purchase of ordnance, and the question, of contested rank between Officers— Left with me the papers relating to all these subjects. J. Reed M.H.R. from Massachusetts complains that the Ordnance is all purchased from three or four Founderies at extravagant prices; instead of advertising for competition, as the Law requires for contracts of supplies— The argument for the founderies from which the purchases are made is that they are very expensive establishments, got up during the late War, at much hazard, and in the Government’s time of need, in the confidence that the Government would purchase exclusively from them— And as there is no demand for the Articles but for the Government, the competition of others if encouraged must be ruinous to them— The subject has already been brought to the notice of Congress the three Sessions last past, but they have not acted upon it— Mr Barbour advises to continue the exclusive purchases as heretofore; that it may be mentioned in the annual report relative to the Condition of the War Department, so that Congress may act upon it if they think proper— He told me he had answered two late Letters from the Governor of Georgia— Asking the appointment of Commissioners on the
on the part of the United States to run boundary lines between the States of Georgia and Alabama—and between Georgia and the Territory of Florida. With the first the United States could not comply, unless at the proposal of Alabama as well as of Georgia; and so Governor Troup had already once been answered, a year since— For the line between Georgia and Florida Commissioners might be appointed by the Government of the United States; but an appropriation for it will be necessary and it will be recommended to Congress at their next Session— D. Brent came for the Instructions to A. H. Everett. H. Clay reported the substance of his Conversations with Obregon the Mexican and Salazar the Colombian Minister, upon the proposal of a Congress of American Ministers to be held at Panama, next October. Mr Clay continues earnest in the desire that a Minister should be appointed to attend this Congress. Mr Barbour urges many objections against it— And on Mr Wirt’s return from Baltimore I propose to have a Meeting of the Members of the Administration to consult upon the expediency of it.— Dr Watkins came to recommend Mr Francis C. Hall for an appointment in the Marine Corps. Samuel Pooley a Journeyman Mathematical Instrument Maker of New-York brought and presented to me a box of miniature knives forks, razors and Scissors made by himself. I told him I made it a general rule to accept no presents; but would make an exception in this case, considering it as a remarkable example of skill and ingenuity, which I should be glad to exhibit as such to my friends— G. Sullivan called after dinner, and I took an hour’s Evening walk with him— He borrowed two Volumes of Milton; and the one, of the Bibliotheque des Philosophes, which contained the first Alcibiades— I slept in the opposite Bed chamber.
28. V:15. symbols 34.35. symbols Morning Thunder Shower.

Mr Daniel Baker Minister of the Second Presbyterian Church came to ask me to lend him money to purchase a dwelling house which is offered to him on very favourable terms— I assented and he is to have the papers drawn. Genl. Brown came and had a long conversation with me upon this question of rank between several Officers in the army— In that between Gaines and Scott he thinks Gaines has the right. He took back a Letter from Governor Clinton to him giving the opinion that there is no use in retaining a military Post at Niagara— The General appears not pleased that the School of practice at Old Point Comfort, or Fortress Monroe, should have been detached from the General administration of the army, and taken under the special charge of the War Department. He attributes it to Mr Calhoun’s excessive thirst of regulating reputation; and turning every thing into instruments for the promotion of his own popularity. He spoke also of the new Army-regulations which he took care to have established by an Order from Mr Monroe, issued almost on the last day of his Administration; but which I told Brown I should take the Liberty to
to revise— Mr William Miller, of North-Carolina, appointed Chargé d’Affaires to Guatemala called—going to New-York. I walked to the Capitol, and went into the Library; where I examined the Newspapers of 1798 and 1799, for evidence relating to the dismission of Captain Isaac Phillips from the Naval Service— I found some, but not that which I had expected— The files of papers are extremely imperfect. Mr Charles F. Mercer and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us— Long sitting and Conversation with Mercer after dinner. Mr N. Biddle President of U.S. Bank had called while I was out— Mrs Adams convalescent, but still quite unwell.
29. V. Bad Night. symbols 36.37. symbols

Southard— S.N. concerning the payment of the six Millions, six per Cents of 1812. he has ascertained that the funds in the Treasury will not suffice to make the payment on the first of July, and concludes to make it the first of October next. Notice is to be issued accordingly. A payment on the first of July would save 45000 dollars of interest, and as the sum in the Treasury will then be within less than a million sufficient, I proposed to effect it by an arrangement with the Bank of the United States, but Mr Southard thinks it not authorised by Law— Mr Biddle the President of the Bank called on me, and I spoke of it to him; but he did not favour it. Biddle was to leave the City this day; returning to Philadelphia. Dr Watkins called with a Mr W. F. Small who had a design for the front of the Capitol: for which a premium has been offered

Parker Daniel brought a memorial respecting the Settlement of his Accts— He claimed double rations as adjutant General; which the Auditor thought him entitled to; but which Cutts the second Comptroller denied; by the direct interposition of the late Secretary of War Calhoun— Parker desired of me a general direction to the accounting officers of the Treasury to settle his accounts on the same principles of those of others. But I told him that was the precise question of the case— That is whether his Office as Adjutant General was one of those entitled to double rations— That if the second Comptroller would state the specific ground of the question, I would decide it; but could not with propriety give any such general direction which would be merely equivalent to ordering them to do their duty.
Hall. F. C. came to solicit an appointment as an Officer in the Marine Corps— Urgent.

Nourse, Joseph. Register proposes to introduce to me a Mr Gallaudet; employed in the Treasury— I shewed Mr Nourse the erroneous charge in the statement of my Accounts printed with the Report of the Committee on those of Mr Monroe. He afterwards sent me a Letter with the Copy of my Account, and the acknowledgment of the error.

Clay. H. Preparing Instructions for A. H. Everett and R. King— He proposes to postpone those of Mr King, excepting upon the Slave indemnity-commission, till after his return from Kentucky: to which I assented— He read me a Letter he had written to Genl. Gaines, resenting the conduct of Gaines’s aid Lieutt. Butler, whom Genl. Brown had introduced to Clay, in my Antichamber, where they met the other day. Butler, who is a connection of Genl. Jackson, evaded taking Clay’s proffered hand— And yesterday Gaines
Gaines left a Card at Clay’s lodgings, but Butler did not. Clay in his Letter said to Gaines that he had supposed Butler’s reason for with holding his hand had been because he had a cutaneous disease.
Pooley— Samuel, the worker of miniature cutlery came and took leave—returning to New-York.
30. V: symbols 38. symbols 39. symbols

Brown— Genl. Conversation with him concerning the new Army regulations— The disputes for rank of Burd and Lomax; and the claim of Captain Baker— The School for Artillery practice at Point Comfort, and the general condition of the army— In the case of Lomax and Burd, the rank having been settled during the suspension of the rules of promotion upon the reduction of the army in 1821. The General thinks it ought not to be unsettled. The claim of Baker he thinks just. In the army Register of this year that Officer was displaced by an arbitrary act, and the date of his Commission set down as about two years later than it had really been issued— I told General Brown I should certainly correct this procedure; and not permit the repetition of it. Brown spoke in high terms of Abraham Eustis, and said he thought he should be brevetted.
Read, Captain of the Navy— A visit— He is on the Court of Enquiry upon Porter.
Waters— A Coll. a Revolution-Officer. Applies for some Appointment.
Gould—Mr. from Boston— Teacher of the Latin School— I was engaged and did not see him.

Clay. H. Brought Letters from C. Hughes and S. Smith of Baltimore— Hughes’s, enclosed copy of an answer received by him from G. Canning, which has put him out of his wits with exultation— His Letter is a Dissertation to prove that the whole Science of Diplomacy consists in giving Dinners—and Smith thinks that our Diplomatic appointments have not strengthened the Administration— Clay wishes to hasten his return to Kentucky; and has had pressing invitations to receive Public Dinners on the road— I advised him not to decline them— He spoke with great bitterness of the appointment by M’Lean the Postmaster General of H. Lee to some informal Office in that Department. Of the infamy of Lee’s character, and his suspicious character even now.

Day. Since my removal to the Presidential Mansion, I rise about five— Read two Chapters of Scott’s Bible and Commentary, and the corresponding commentary of Hewlett— Then the morning Newspapers, and public papers from the several Departments— Write seldom, and not enough— Breakfast; an hour from nine to ten— Then have a succession of visitors, upon business, in search of place, Solicitors for donations; or for mere curiosity, from eleven, till between 4 and 5. O’Clock— The Heads of Departments of course occupy much of this time. Between four and six I take a walk of three or four Miles. Dine from about half past five till seven, and from dark till about eleven, I generally pass the Evening in my chamber, signing Land-grants or Blank Patents; in the interval of which for the last ten days, I have brought up three Months of Arrears in my Diary-Index— About eleven I retire to bed. My Evenings are not so free from interruption as I had hoped and expected they would be; nor have I the prospect of methodising the distribution of my time to my own Satisfaction— There is much to correct, and reform, and the precept of Diligence is always timely—
